abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Nusa Tenggara
            Agricultural Support Project for Indonesia were as follows:
            outcomes were satisfactory, project sustainability was
            likely, Bank performance was satisfactory, and Borrower
            performance was also a satisfactory. Some lessons learned
            included: the pace and quality of implementation was lacking
            during the initial years, but once the project organization
            took roots and became operational, it worked satisfactorily
            and resulted in the satisfactory achievement of the
            financial, physical and development objectives of the
            project. However, a more substantial role of the provincial
            Kanwil of the Ministry of Agriculture in providing technical
            back-up will have improved the quality of implementation of
            the agricultural components. While these decentralized
            implementation arrangements helped in satisfactory physical
            implementation of the overall project, as well as provided
            opportunities for 'learning by doing' to a large
            number of local level agencies and staff, the wide range of
            activities under the provincial component strained the
            limited capabilities of the local level institutions and
            affected the quality of implementation and their development
            impact. Block financial allocations appeared attractive due
            to their flexibility and being demand responsive, but they
            also promoted too many loosely hanging activities without
            proper management and technical back-up, and often with
            doubtful viability. While maintaining flexibility in funding
            and implementation arrangements will be important for
            ensuring participatory and sustainable development, the
            critical need to establish criteria or parameters for the
            selection of project activities on the basis of realistic
            assessment of priorities can not be over emphasized.
